articles.title: Semiconductor Demand
articles.description: Semiconductor demand in the past 35 years.
articles.contents:
Raw Data
This is the raw data from the original xls file downloaded from the
website.

# A tibble: 225 × 18
   `36 Years WSTS…` ...2  ...3  ...4  ...5  `1986 to Date` ...7  ...8 
   <chr>            <chr> <chr> <chr> <chr> <chr>          <chr> <chr>
 1 © 2022 By WSTS,… <NA>  <NA>  <NA>  <NA>  <NA>           <NA>  <NA> 
 2 All numbers are… <NA>  <NA>  <NA>  <NA>  <NA>           <NA>  <NA> 
 3 <NA>             Janu… Febr… March April May            June  July 
 4 1986             <NA>  <NA>  <NA>  <NA>  <NA>           <NA>  <NA> 
 5 Americas         5558… 6334… 7562… 6894… 718336         7970… 7077…
 6 Europe           3464… 4017… 4619… 4367… 446171         4725… 4394…
 7 Japan            6385… 7503… 8402… 8380… 870515         9224… 9968…
 8 Asia Pacific     1050… 1157… 1479… 1564… 167537         1850… 1860…
 9 Worldwide        1645… 1901… 2206… 2120… 2202559        2377… 2330…
10 1987             <NA>  <NA>  <NA>  <NA>  <NA>           <NA>  <NA> 
# … with 215 more rows, and 10 more variables: ...9 <chr>,
#   ...10 <chr>, ...11 <chr>, ...12 <chr>, ...13 <chr>, ...14 <chr>,
#   ...15 <chr>, ...16 <chr>, ...17 <chr>, ...18 <chr>

Looking at this, it isn’t pretty. The years are in the same column as
the countries, column names are all messed up do to how this was
formatted; so then it was time to wrangle it into place.
Wrangling
Scanning through the data, it was clear that we needed to first
change the names of these columns, because they were all messed up.
Furthermore, the countries column has the years in it. That isn’t
right. So we need a new column to hold the years, then delete all of the
ones from where they aren’t supposed to be.
After polishing this dataset into something usable, here it is!

# A tibble: 144 × 19
   Regions      January February March  April May   June  July  August
   <chr>        <chr>   <chr>    <chr>  <chr> <chr> <chr> <chr> <chr> 
 1 Americas     555850  633465   756220 6894… 7183… 7970… 7077… 697506
 2 Europe       346467  401765   461912 4367… 4461… 4725… 4394… 426172
 3 Japan        638547  750366   840215 8380… 8705… 9224… 9968… 914476
 4 Asia Pacific 105050  115746   147968 1564… 1675… 1850… 1860… 187628
 5 Americas     662316  695384   879953 7830… 8190… 9340… 8517… 875491
 6 Europe       446216  460982   551635 4831… 5226… 5422… 4593… 456098
 7 Japan        839651  885850   947246 9373… 9803… 1064… 1093… 10000…
 8 Asia Pacific 189473  218174   258402 2703… 2859… 3077… 2997… 290902
 9 Americas     905615  960564   11289… 1016… 1081… 1248… 1119… 11622…
10 Europe       549355  619132   755057 6468… 6666… 7669… 5864… 608248
# … with 134 more rows, and 10 more variables: September <chr>,
#   October <chr>, November <chr>, December <chr>, Total_Year <dbl>,
#   Q1 <chr>, Q2 <chr>, Q3 <chr>, Q4 <chr>, year <int>

Semiconductor Demand
From Four Regions
Historical billings of semiconductor demand from the Americas, the
Asia Pacific, Europe, and Japan are shown here.



(WSTS
1986)
There is a massive increase in in the Asia Pacific Region, peaking at
almost 343 million semiconductor units reported to be purchased.
The semiconductor demand in the Americas have steadily increased, but
nowhere near the growth of the Asia Pacific region.
Demand for semiconductors in Europe and Japan have been relatively
low, and there haven’t been any particularly high amounts of growth
demand for them either.



WSTS. 1986. World Semiconductor Trade Statistics Historical Billigns
Report. WSTS. https://www.wsts.org/67/Historical-Billings-Report.

articles.title: Microchip Market
articles.description: Welcome to the website. I hope you enjoy it!
articles.contents:
Introduction
How many of you have wondered what exactly is in your computer? Based
on this article’s title, you’ve probably guessed already.
Semiconductors. These little chips in your phones and computers are the
center for their core operations as well as advanced capabilities.

articles.title: Source A
articles.contents:
Distill is a publication format for scientific and technical writing,
native to the web.
Learn more about using Distill for R Markdown at https://rstudio.github.io/distill.
